Indeed, Ms. Barton believes that the Christian imagery used in those alleged rituals are a perverted use of their "propaganda" to keep themselves in power.

Following is a list of incidents that were described as having some link to the occult. The stories were taken from news accounts and interviews with police. Most of the incidents remain under investigation or are not linked to Satanism:

MONMOUTH COUNTY
Two Freehold men were arrested in their home on charges of possessing 300 grams of marijuana. They said they were using it for "religious purposes." The marijuana was seized that night by police. They said they were members of the Church of Satan.

OCEAN COUNTY
Police in Berkeley Township found hundreds of hand-written satanic symbols and evidence of bonfires behind the residences of two teenage girls. One girl showed a small wrist during from July, the Devil said. "I love you."

Police believe another girl, a Toms River, police investigated a report that youths held an alleged satanic worship ritual in the woods. A witness saw a woman wearing a white robe in the secluded house last year, police found unidentified animal bones in the yard.

In Ocean County woman reported Thursday that a group of juveniles who knocked on her door and asked her children were freed to escape because they believed Satan was after them. The woman reported the ring of trash to it.

MIDDLESEX COUNTY  
In Metuchen, Middlesex resident reported that he was a group of juveniles meeting for satanic worship rituals. However, police investigating an area cornfield had they found candles arranged around a circle. They discovered no other physical evidence at the scene, said Detective Art Paulowski. "We're getting a lot of reports about this type of incident," he said.

BERGEN COUNTY
Waldwick police reported receiving several calls from residents concerned about youths in a wooded area. One witness said he heard chanting and saw lights during nighttime hours in October of 1988. An investigating officer found burned wood, rocks arranged in a circle and what appeared to be an animal skull.

MORRIS COUNTY
The parents said teenaged boys have had their cars painted with satanic red slogans and pictures during from the 1986. Police say this has been in association with vandalism at area churches. Vandalism included pentagrams, crosses and 666, the number associated with evil.

Dead animals most common

Police believe people involved were teenagers who congregated on the New Year's Day in Shire section in 1988.

In South Toms River, police investigated reports of painted faces and satanic messages on mailboxes near a vacant house last year, police found unidentified animal bones in a wooded area in the yard.

An Ocean County woman reported Thursday that a group of juveniles who knocked on her door and asked her if children were freed because they believed Satan was after them. The woman reported the ring of trash to it.

Also in Lakewood a Lakewood resident said she and her children were freed to escape because they believed Satan was after them. The woman turned over a gold pentagram, ring author of "Guide to Criminal and Police Law," in which she relates several aspects of satanic crime. "We are finding evidence such as graffiti or animals, not crimes," said Sgt. William Kotrch of Morris Township Police. "Police have been investigating these types of allegations. We've been told by people who claim there are satanic cults operating in the central New Jersey area that are active at night," wrote author Arthur Lyons.

Ms. Barton, of the Church of Satan, condemned the behavior described in most these criminal activities, but she does not believe they're Satanists.

"And I ought to be in a position to know," she said.

Senior detective Tom Napier, head of the central New Jersey gang unit says he has seen an increase in evidence may have evidence such as graffiti or animals, not crimes.

"There is no evidence that there is evidence that people were being murdered and are involved in Satanism," he said as to what's dangerous or what's being done by people who are engaging in something they think is acceptable.

stories.headline: Expert: Normal Youths Sent to Mental Hospitals
stories.text:
TRENTON (AP) — Youths without psychiatric problems are being committed to state mental hospitals because of a lack of bed space in county juvenile detention centers, according to a top New Jersey psychiatric official.

Dr. Michail Rotov, director of the state Division of Mental Health and Hospitals, said he did a personal study "for my own purposes" at one institution.

"Of 16 youths committed over a period of time by judges, sometimes at the urging of parents, only one — in my professional opinion — had any reason to be sent to a mental hospital," he said.

Interviews with Rotov and other state officials were published Monday in The Star-Ledger of Newark.

"I'm unclear about the reasons why an 11-year-old child with the diagnosis of hyperactivity, had to remain confined in that place for 11 months," Rotov said.

Another psychiatrist who asked not to be identified said about 80 of the 120 youths committed over a period of time at an unnamed state facility "did not have to be put in a mental hospital, mingling in the same wards and special schools as kids with acute mental illness."

The newspaper also reported Monday that children who run away from a foster home or a county shelter can then be charged with juvenile delinquency, and because of limited facilities at some county detention centers, they are sent to mental institutions until bed space can be found for them.

Although the state Public Advocate's office said it was concerned with the situation, the office does not have the authority to stop a judge or parent from committing the youth, especially if there are not adequate facilities elsewhere for those with behavioral problems.

In many of the cases, the newspaper reported, children are being sent to the institutions under an archaic 15-day commitment law. In almost all cases, there is no advance certifications by a psychiatrist that the youths require commitment in a mental hospital.

Youths whose welfare is in the hands of state agencies, such as the Division of Youth and Family Services, also are being committed, the newspaper reported. The children may be abused or suffering other effects of broken homes, although they are not mentally ill.

"About half a dozen who were DYFS cases spent an excessive amount of time in the hospital — more than three months — possibly because of placement difficulties," Rotov said referring to his study.

Marcia Richman of the Public Advocate's office and some juvenile judges said that institutions often are being used an an alternative because of a shortage of beds for children with social and behavioral problems in the residential schools and special homes.

Rotov said children with behavioral problems emanating from retardation or epilepsy, cerebral palsy and encephalitis are wrongfully committed to mental institutions.

"These kids aren't dangerous to themselves or anyone else, in many cases. Unfortunately, there's no better place to put them than in a mental institution. It's a very shabby situation," said Ms. Richman.

stories.headline: Making music from unlikely sources
stories.text:
Continued from Page 21

Uncut dowels used by furniture makers to cover screw holes. The varying lengths of dowel rise up from the sculpture's round pineboard base in a circular staircase pattern.

Whitecage bows the wooden dowel sticks with a cello bow, making haunting, primal first-day-of-creation sounds, which are amplified by an acoustic bass's electronic pickup attached to the pine board with putty.

The sounds from the bowed dowels resonate in a steel salad bowl turned up-side-down beneath the base and in five square, bent sheets of steel which flower above the dowels from a central metal post. The salad bowl can be moved to create a vibrato effect.

"The reason I need so many," he said, referring to the steel sheets, "is certain frequencies resonate in certain size steels."

A few years ago, Whitecage exhibited 14 Sound Sculptures at the former O'Roe Gallery in Hoboken, and the public was allowed to play the musical sculptures, which he generally keeps for performances now.

But he is currently constructing several Sound Sculptures he calls "boards," colorfully painted and part naturally-finished wooden boards with strings that can be strummed like a harp. When Whitecage has made more boards, he says, he will exhibit them for the public to play.

Whitecage will be playing sax with jazz clarinetist Perry Robinson, guitarist Josh Rubin and the Space/Time Swing Band on Sept. 3 at Maxwell's, 1039 Washington St., Hoboken, and with Joe Ruddick at Hoboken's River City Fair on Sept. 13.

stories.headline: Did hospital records survive time? Snake Hill asylum history
stories.text:
I'm researching my family history and I'm looking for information about the mental hospital in Secaucus operating earlier this century known as Snake Hill. My great grandmother was there about 1916. Are there any patient records still available from this facility? — Genealogy Buff, Jersey City

There is a fair amount of general historical information about Snake Hill and other county facilities that were operated at that site in Secaucus, but Hudson County has no patient records from the mental hospital itself.

Hudson County keeps mental hospital records for 20 years after a patient death or 10 years after a discharge, said employee Florence Bricker. Snake Hill, then known as Laurel Hill, was closed by the early 1960s, said Dan McDonough of Secaucus, associate town historian for the town.

The Secaucus Historical Centre, operated by McDonough and Town Historian H. Roger Gilbert, has about 150 photographs and other materials covering the history of the site, McDonough said.

The site, a present-day home to the Hudson County Jail Annex and former home to the "Tent City" jail facility, housed a "poor farm," a tuberculosis ward, a children's eye clinic, a prison and an alms house as well as mental hospitals since Hudson County purchased the site from Bergen County around 1840. Joan Lovero, local historian and librarian at the New Jersey Room of the Jersey City Public Library Main Branch, says the site may have been purchased as early as the 1820s.

The county does have arrest records for some arrested and held at the Hudson County Penitentiary, near the mental hospital, McDonough said.

The complex was known as Snake Hill because of a huge rock formation of that name that sits rather dramatically in the middle of low-lying swamp land. The rock is now known locally as "Frat Rock" because it is covered with graffiti of fraternity and sorority symbols, McDonough said. "The New Jersey Turnpike runs over the rock between exits 15E and 16E," he said. A smokestack and some building foundations from the old facilities are still visible at the site.

From its opening to the 1860s, the poor, elderly and others unable to support themselves were given drained swamp land on the site and expected to grow their own food, Lovero said. By the 1860s, she added, there was a tuberculosis hospital and a mental hospital adjacent to the poor farm. The mental hospital, in the uncharitable jargon of the time, was known as the Hudson County Lunatic Asylum, McDonough said.

By 1906, the hospital was known as the Hudson County Insane Asylum, McDonough said. About 75 photos from a large open house held that year also reveal a children's eye clinic, three churches, the Hudson County Penitentiary, a bakery, an alms house and more than 30 buildings in total. The director that year was Frank McGee. The whole complex, which also included an active waterfront on the Hackensack River, was self-sustaining and actually productive enough to export bread for local sale, McDonough said.

Prisoners quarried Snake Hill itself, pounding stone into road gravel for New Jersey Trap Rock, he said.

Snake Hill became Laurel Hill around the time your great-grandmother was a patient, when a freeholder described it as the "crowning laurel" of the county, McDonough said.

stories.headline: Experts debunk Satanism theory - Skulls investigation
stories.text:
EWING — In other places, they have chicken slaughter, wild cat killings. Now New Jersey has horse murders.

Is it Satan?

Experts say no. Three satanism scholars said yesterday the five skulls that appear to be horse heads that may be cattle heads? found near the River Edge apartment complex are almost certainly not part of a satanic ritual. Nevertheless, some local officials theorized occult ritualists were responsible.

"You don't have to be critical to see such a thing as an occult ritual," said Jeffrey Victor, a sociology professor at Jamestown Community College in upstate New York. "There are lots of people who are mentally disturbed criminals who may call themselves satanists, but they're not Satan worshipers. These are people who say they can themselves satanists and con artists who promote the idea that satanic cults are a menace. This whole thing is what folklore starts in popular culture and is copied."

He and others who study what is popularly known as Satanism — which includes animal killings like chickens in worship, a ritual that some people confuse with ceremonies involving the sacrifice of horses or cattle being used in such rituals. They said rituals don't involve the killing of large animals.

"Satanic" are usually the work of teenagers who watch horror movies and dress up in costumes and capes and perform a supposedly satanic ritual.

ACCORDING TO Victor, what he calls the great satanic cult scare around 1980 and intensified in 1983, when the McMartin day-care case in California was in the news. In that case, the accused day-care providers in Manhattan Beach were alleged to have been involved in a satanic cult. In the ensuing months and years, parents around the country pulled their children out of day-care centers because they were afraid the children would be kidnapped by satanists.

The satanic cult scare was kicked off in the 1960s, when a rumor started in Idaho that satanists were killing Christian children, sacrificing them and drinking their blood.

"These scares have swept North America, Europe, Australia, New Zealand and communities of people of northern Europe have extended their belief in the existence of satanic activity. Absolutely no reliable evidence has been found in the investigations by police. What is there is an organized satanic cult that fits the folklore."

By DEBORAH KOVACH
Staff Writer

Christians were accused of kidnapping Roman children and sacrificing them in secret rituals, he said.

Perry Ann Modica, a Levittown resident who lectures and writes about some of the dangers of the occult, said she has never heard of the use of cattle skulls being used in satanic ritual. Unlike Victor, she believes satanic cults do exist.

"Unless there is evidence of a bonfire or ritual going on — I mean, satanic rituals are very elaborate — it's not evidence of a satanic ritual or not," she said.

Modica cautioned against concluding anything strange crime is the work of satanists.

"People don't have to be called satanists to be doing any strange crime. We don't see Satanism in everything," she said. "It it was found at a cult or a site where they were actually worshipping or not. That's where hysteria can enter in."

Hysteria is what the satanism scare is all about, says Phillip Stevens Jr., associate professor of anthropology at the State University of New York at Buffalo.

"A SATANIC explanation is about as rational as saying space aliens abducted the cattle," Stevens said. "When people find themselves not responsible in making pronouncements against things tend to take the stance they are being too quick to dismiss a crime," he said. "The police themselves have asked the media to withhold, delay or graduate the concern."

Satanism is a Western Christian narrative tradition and timeless speculation. It is an outgrowth of Christian thinking against the fundamental structure of Western society. Basic elements of the satanic cult folklore be found throughout the world and throughout history, always at times of stress, often economic stress, and always in times of rapid social change.

Like Victor, Stevens dates the start of the current hysteria to about 1980.

Police are looking for three men aged 20 to 24 who are identified as either Hispanic or white.

The driver has tanned skin and brown hair, and was wearing a black baseball cap. The car is possibly white or silver. The driver is approximately 6 feet tall, with black hair, wearing a black jacket and red shirt, dark pants, and white and black sneakers. He spoke with an accent.

A third man is described only as wearing a sports jacket.

State Police are assisting in the investigation, and have compiled composite sketches of the two men the boy encountered.

Anyone with any information on the incident should call the Pennington Police Dept. at 737-2020 or State Police Detective Sgt. Steve Wolfer at 882-3652.

stories.headline: One Year Later: Montclair Musician Still Missing After Mirror Gallery Show
stories.text:
MONTCLAIR - It has been one year since 22-year-old guitarist Eric Mendez vanished from the stage at the Big Orb, a Bloomfield Avenue club that has since closed its doors. Despite extensive investigation by Montclair Police, no trace of Mendez has been found, and the case remains open as a missing person investigation.

Mendez was the lead guitarist for Temporal Distortion, a four-piece noise rock band that, according to those who attended shows, was "ahead of its time" in a local scene still dominated by hair metal acts. On the night of October 17, 1990, the band was performing what witnesses describe as an unusually intense set.

"The whole night felt wrong," said former drummer Jake Castellano, now attending Rutgers University. "We were playing faster than we'd ever played before. I remember looking at my watch between songs and thinking the time didn't make sense."

The show was booked alongside an art installation by Sarah Vance, a Montclair State graduate student whose "Mirror Gallery" consisted of seventeen large mirrors positioned throughout the club's performance space and backstage area. According to the police report, Vance's installation was intended to explore "perception and temporal reflection."

Multiple witnesses reported seeing Mendez in several mirrors simultaneously during the band's final song, despite his physical position on stage. "I was watching him play, but in the mirror behind him, I could see him facing a different direction, playing different notes," said audience member Lisa Chen, then a senior at Montclair High School. "Then the music just stopped."

According to band members, Mendez had stepped backstage between songs - a break lasting what they estimated as "maybe thirty seconds" - but when Castellano went to check on him, he was gone. Mendez's guitar was found leaning against one of Vance's mirrors, still plugged into his amplifier, which continued to emit a low hum.

A recording of the performance, made by the club's sound engineer on a four-track cassette, contains what audio analyst Thomas Brewster describes as "significant anomalies." 

"There's a four-minute gap where the master tape shows continuous recording, but there's complete silence - not even room noise," said Brewster, who examined the tape at the family's request. "Then when sound returns, there are frequencies present that shouldn't be audible on analog equipment of that era. Some of the tones measure above 20 kHz."

Police found no evidence of foul play. Mendez's wallet, keys, and jacket were recovered from the backstage area. His car remained in the club's parking lot. Several witnesses reported seeing someone matching Mendez's description walking on Bloomfield Avenue in the early morning hours after the show, but these sightings were never confirmed.

Sarah Vance's mirror installation was dismantled the following week. When contacted for this article, Vance declined to comment, saying only that she had "moved on from that period of work." The mirrors themselves have not been located; Vance claims they were disposed of, though no records of this disposal exist.

The Big Orb closed in March 1991, with the owners citing "declining interest in the local music scene" and "unspecified insurance issues." The building now houses a copy center.

For Mendez's family, the lack of closure has been devastating. "Eric was excited about that show," said his mother, Patricia Mendez. "He called me that afternoon and said they were playing with some kind of art thing, that it was going to be 'transformative.' Those were his exact words. I keep thinking about that."

The remaining members of Temporal Distortion have not performed together since that night. When asked about the band's setlist, Castellano produced a crumpled piece of paper with song titles and tempo markings. The final song, titled "Information Seeking Flesh," was marked "182 BPM."

"We'd never played it that fast before," Castellano said. "But that night, it felt like the only speed that made sense. Like we were locked into something and couldn't slow down even if we wanted to."

Anyone with information about Eric Mendez's whereabouts is asked to contact Montclair Police Department at (973) 744-1234.

stories.headline: The Mendez Pedal: Homemade Fuzz Box Produces Impossible Transmissions
stories.text:
By Marcus Webb

When Eric Mendez disappeared from the Big Orb stage in October 1990, he left behind more than an unsolved mystery. Among his effects was a hand-built fuzz pedal, constructed from scavenged electronics and housed in a gutted Electro-Harmonix Big Muff case. For over a year, this pedal sat in an evidence locker at Montclair Police Department.

Last month, Jake Castellano - Mendez's former drummer in Temporal Distortion - was finally allowed to retrieve Eric's gear. What he discovered has both fascinated and disturbed the small circle of people who've heard it.

"I plugged it in just to test it," Castellano told me at his off-campus apartment in New Brunswick. "I wasn't even playing anything. Just turned it on. And it started... talking."

The pedal, when activated and connected to an amplifier, produces what sounds like human speech played in reverse. But here's where it gets strange: when Castellano recorded the output and played it backwards, the speech didn't resolve into normal English. Instead, it produced a different set of backwards-sounding words.

"It's like it's stuck in reverse," said audio engineer Thomas Brewster, the same analyst who examined the Big Orb recordings. "I've worked with tape loops, I've worked with feedback systems, I've worked with every kind of signal processing you can imagine. This shouldn't be possible with passive analog circuitry. There's no power supply beyond the 9-volt battery. There's no sampling, no digital memory. But it's producing phonemes - recognizable speech sounds - without any input signal."

Brewster and I spent an afternoon analyzing the pedal. The circuit board inside is a chaotic assembly of mismatched components: transistors from different decades, capacitors of wildly different values, and what appears to be part of a CB radio crystal oscillator. Written on the inside of the enclosure in silver paint: "182" and a series of numbers that might be coordinates: "40.8157, -74.2107."

Those coordinates, when entered into a GPS system, point to a location in the Pine Barrens approximately 47 miles southeast of Montclair.

The backwards speech itself is difficult to parse. Castellano has recorded over forty minutes of output from the pedal, all of it producing similar phonetic patterns. Linguist Dr. Sarah Okonkwo of Rutgers analyzed several samples and noted that the reversed speech "contains prosodic elements consistent with English, but the phoneme sequences don't match any known language when played forward OR backward."

However, certain phrases repeat. One segment, when played backwards, sounds remarkably like "the mirrors remember." Another sounds like "frequency equals location." A third - and this is what convinced me to write this article - sounds exactly like someone saying "October seventeenth, 11:47 PM" when played forward at half speed.

That's the exact date and approximate time of Mendez's disappearance.

"Eric was always into weird gear," said bassist Monica Torres, another Temporal Distortion member who has since moved to Philadelphia. "He built that pedal over the summer of 1990. Said he was trying to make something that would 'translate between states.' I thought he meant, like, clean tone to distortion. Now I don't know what he meant."

According to Torres, Mendez had become increasingly interested in theories about sound and consciousness. "He was reading all this stuff about binaural beats, about how certain frequencies could alter perception. He kept talking about 182 hertz being some kind of 'carrier frequency.' He said most fuzz pedals just destroy information, but he wanted to build one that would REVEAL information."

The pedal's circuit design is bizarre even by noise electronics standards. Several components appear to be installed backwards from conventional wiring. The transistors are arranged in what appears to be an attempt at a ring modulator, but the topology doesn't match any known design. Most peculiarly, there's a small coil of copper wire wrapped exactly seventeen times around the battery compartment.

"If I didn't know better, I'd say he was trying to build a radio receiver," Brewster said. "But receiving from where? The frequencies this thing is responding to aren't allocated to any broadcast service. They're in the gaps."

When I asked Castellano if he planned to continue using the pedal, he shook his head.

"I plugged it in one more time last week," he said. "The backwards speech changed. It wasn't repeating anymore. It said - and I'm pretty sure about this - it said 'Jake, don't look for me.' Forward, backwards, it didn't matter. Same message both ways."

He unplugged it immediately. The pedal is now stored in Castellano's closet, disconnected and wrapped in a towel.

"Sometimes I can hear it through the wall," he said. "Even without power. Just a faint hum. Always at night. Always the same frequency."

I asked him if he'd measured the frequency.

"182 hertz," he said. "Exactly."

Patricia Mendez, Eric's mother, declined to comment for this article. When I mentioned the coordinates found in the pedal, she hung up the phone.

Montclair Police maintain that Eric Mendez left voluntarily and that there is no evidence of foul play. The pedal, they say, is "personal property with no evidentiary value."

As for the coordinates? I drove out there last week. It's deep Pine Barrens, fire roads and scrub pine. There's an old abandoned radio tower about a quarter mile from the exact point. Someone had spraypainted on the concrete base: "THE SIGNAL FINDS ITS OWN FREQUENCY."

The paint was fresh.

[Editor's note: After this article was typeset, Jake Castellano contacted us to report that the pedal has gone missing from his apartment. There were no signs of forced entry.]

stories.headline: Writer Hospitalized After Assault; Cult Members Sought in Electronics Theft
stories.text:
NEW BRUNSWICK - Marcus Webb, 24, a freelance music journalist, was treated at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital Sunday evening following an assault at his Morris Avenue apartment. Three suspects remain at large.

According to New Brunswick Police, Webb returned home around 7:30 PM to find his apartment door forced open. Three individuals, described by Webb as wearing identical gray windbreakers and black pants, confronted him in his living room.

"They kept saying they needed 'the transmission device,'" Webb told police. "They were very calm about it, very organized. One of them kept checking his watch and saying they were 'running out of orbital window.'"

The suspects were seeking a homemade guitar effects pedal that had been the subject of Webb's recent article in New Jersey Underground, a local music publication. The pedal, built by missing Montclair musician Eric Mendez, had been in the possession of Jake Castellano, a Rutgers student and former bandmate of Mendez.

According to the police report, when Webb stated he did not have the pedal, one suspect produced what appeared to be a frequency counter or similar electronic device. "He said his meter was reading '182 hertz' and that meant the device was 'still proximate,'" Webb reported. "He kept sweeping the room with it like a metal detector."

The suspects then demanded to know the location of "the Pine Barrens coordinates." When Webb hesitated, he was struck twice in the face and pushed against a wall. The assailants then systematically searched his apartment, taking audio cassettes, his article notes, and a map of southern New Jersey with several locations marked.

A neighbor, hearing the commotion, knocked on the door, causing the suspects to flee. They departed in what witnesses describe as a white panel van with no visible plates or markings. One witness noted a symbol on the van's side door: a circle with seventeen radial lines.

Webb sustained facial bruising and a mild concussion but was released from the hospital Monday morning.

Jake Castellano, reached at his off-campus residence, confirmed that the Mendez pedal had disappeared from his apartment one week prior. "I filed a police report, but they said it was probably just stolen by someone who read the article and wanted weird gear," Castellano said. "Now I'm not so sure."

Castellano has agreed to stay with friends temporarily and has asked that his current location not be disclosed.

New Brunswick Police Detective Sarah Mims said the incident appears related to a series of similar break-ins targeting electronics and recording equipment in central New Jersey over the past month. "We're seeing a pattern of thefts involving audio equipment, particularly vintage or homemade devices," Mims said. "The suspects seem to have specific knowledge of what they're looking for."

When asked about the suspects' unusual statements regarding "orbital windows" and frequency meters, Mims declined to comment, saying only that "the investigation is ongoing."

Patricia Mendez, mother of missing guitarist Eric Mendez, was contacted by police as a precautionary measure. She declined to speak with reporters but issued a statement through her attorney requesting that "those interested in my son's effects and belongings respect our family's privacy during this difficult time."

The three suspects are described as males in their late twenties to early thirties, approximately 5'10" to 6' tall, with short hair. One suspect wore glasses with heavily tinted lenses despite the evening hour. All three wore what Webb described as "matching digital watches."

Anyone with information is asked to contact New Brunswick Police at (732) 745-5217.

In a possibly related incident, a white panel van matching the description was reported seen at a fire road entrance near Lebanon State Forest in the Pine Barrens early Monday morning. Bass River State Forest rangers noted the van was parked near an abandoned radio tower but had departed before rangers could investigate. Fresh tire tracks led approximately two miles into restricted forest area before disappearing on hardpacked sand.

No arrests have been made.

stories.headline: State Police, Forest Rangers Report Temporal Anomaly at Pine Barrens Radio Tower; 17 Missing
stories.text:
BASS RIVER STATE FOREST - New Jersey State Police and the Department of Environmental Protection have cordoned off a 3-mile radius around an abandoned radio tower in Bass River State Forest following what officials are calling "an incident of undetermined nature" that resulted in seventeen people being reported missing.

The incident occurred Tuesday evening at approximately 11:47 PM, according to official reports, though multiple inconsistencies in documented timelines have complicated the investigation.

State Forest Rangers Michael Corben and Lisa Huang were investigating reports of trespassing near the decommissioned tower when they observed what Huang described as "a gathering of individuals in gray windbreakers arranged in a circular pattern around electronic equipment."

According to both rangers' written reports - filed separately and without consultation - the group was using what appeared to be a guitar effects pedal connected to a car battery and a portable amplifier. The device was producing "a sustained tone at extreme volume."

"The tone was physically painful," Corben's report states. "But more disturbing was that it seemed to be coming from multiple directions simultaneously. Ranger Huang was standing to my left, but I could hear her voice coming from my right. When I looked at my watch, the second hand was moving backwards."

State Police arrived at 11:52 PM in response to the rangers' radio call. Trooper James Kellerman's dashboard camera captured approximately four minutes of footage before the camera's timestamp began displaying "ERROR" and the date "10/17/1990."

The footage, which has been reviewed by this reporter, shows the following sequence of events:

11:52:17 PM - Police vehicle approaches. Headlights illuminate approximately 17 individuals standing in a circle.

11:52:33 PM - All individuals turn simultaneously to face the police vehicle, though none appear to move their feet.

11:52:41 PM - The audio track captures a sustained tone. A voice, gender indeterminate, states: "The frequency is the location. The location is the time."

11:53:09 PM - Video displays severe distortion. When image clears, the circle of individuals has vanished. The equipment remains.

11:53:09 PM - Timestamp does not advance. All subsequent frames show identical timestamp for 47 seconds of footage.

11:47:00 PM - Timestamp jumps backward. Displays this time for remainder of recording before camera failure.

Trooper Kellerman's written report states: "I exited my vehicle and approached the location where the subjects had been standing. The ground was covered with frost in a perfect circular pattern, despite air temperature of 73 degrees Fahrenheit. My flashlight beam would not enter the circle - the light stopped at the frost line as if hitting a solid surface."

Rangers Corben and Huang corroborate this observation. Huang's report adds: "I attempted to photograph the frost circle with my service camera. When the film was later developed, every frame taken at the site shows the same image: a mirror reflecting my own face, though no mirror was present at the scene."

The guitar effects pedal, later identified as the device constructed by missing Montclair musician Eric Mendez, was recovered at the scene. It was still connected to the amplifier and battery, though the battery measured zero voltage when tested. The pedal itself was frozen solid, with internal temperature measuring -40 degrees Fahrenheit despite the warm evening.

Most disturbing: when the pedal was later thawed and activated in a State Police laboratory, it produced a recording of the officers' own voices from the incident - but speaking words they had not yet said at the time of the original event.

"The pedal played back my voice saying 'seventeen disappeared at the tower site' approximately six hours before I wrote that phrase in my official report," stated Detective William Monroe of the State Police Major Crimes Unit. "We have verified this timeline through laboratory logs. The device somehow recorded a future statement."

The frost circle measured exactly 17 feet in diameter. Within the circle, all vegetation was found to be dead, though botanical analysis suggests the plant matter died "several weeks ago" despite the area having been inspected by rangers just two days prior with no abnormalities noted.

Soil samples taken from within the circle contain pollen from plants that do not grow in New Jersey and, according to Rutgers botanist Dr. Helen Kraft, "shouldn't exist in this geological period."

Seventeen pairs of black shoes were found arranged in a perfect circle on the frost line, all pointing inward. The shoes show no wear on the soles despite their owners presumably walking several miles into the forest. Each shoe contains a digital watch, all stopped at precisely 11:47 PM. The watches, when examined, have date displays reading "10/17/1990" - the date of Eric Mendez's disappearance.

No footprints lead away from the site. Search teams with dogs found no trace of the missing individuals. Helicopter thermal imaging detected no human heat signatures in a 10-mile radius.

More puzzling: the abandoned radio tower, which according to DEP records has been non-functional since 1978, was found to be broadcasting a signal on an unlicensed frequency when engineers investigated Wednesday morning. The signal consists of a 182-hertz carrier tone modulated with what audio analysts describe as "human speech played in both directions simultaneously."

FCC engineers who attempted to shut down the transmission reported that their equipment malfunctioned upon approaching the tower. "Every meter we brought within 100 feet of the structure began displaying impossible readings," said senior field engineer Robert Chen. "Our frequency counter showed negative hertz. Our thermometers showed temperatures in Kelvin that would require absolute zero plus additional cooling that violates thermodynamics."

The tower continues to broadcast as of press time. The FCC has classified the frequency as a "navigational hazard" and issued warnings to aircraft.

State Police have released descriptions of three individuals believed to have organized the gathering, matching those sought in connection with the New Brunswick assault of music journalist Marcus Webb. However, authorities admit they cannot explain how seventeen people vanished from a location under direct observation.

"I've been with State Police for 22 years," said Captain Douglas Merritt, head of the investigation. "I've never filed a report like this. Multiple trained observers, dashboard camera footage, physical evidence - and I still can't tell you what happened. The only thing I know for certain is that seventeen people were present at 11:52 PM and absent at 11:53 PM, and the laws of physics appeared to be optional during that one-minute interval."

The DEP has closed Bass River State Forest indefinitely. The radio tower site is under 24-hour guard, though guards report "significant difficulties" with electronic equipment and timekeeping devices.

Patricia Mendez, mother of Eric Mendez, released a statement through her attorney Wednesday evening: "If my son's device was involved in these events, I can only say that Eric was searching for something. Perhaps he found it. I pray those missing people find their way back."

Jake Castellano, former drummer of Temporal Distortion and the last person known to possess the Mendez pedal, could not be reached for comment.

The white panel van reportedly used by the suspects was found abandoned near the Garden State Parkway's Exit 50, approximately 15 miles from the tower site. Inside the van, State Police found 17 sleeping bags, 17 boxes of energy bars, and a hand-drawn map marking the tower location with the note: "Carrier frequency achieves manifestation threshold 11:47 PM, June 23, 1992. Prepare for transmission."

The map was dated October 15, 1990 - two days before Eric Mendez disappeared.

Anyone with information regarding the missing individuals should contact New Jersey State Police at (609) 882-2000.
stories.location: Bass River State Forest, New Jersey

stories.headline: Police Blotter - March 12, 1987
stories.text:
BOARDWALK - 2:34 AM: Officers responded to complaint about "music from empty arcade." Palace Amusements employee reported hearing band playing inside locked building. Officers found no signs of forced entry. Employee insisted music was "live performance, not recording" and included "drums, guitar, everything." No equipment found inside. Employee stated band was playing "really fast, like punk rock." When asked to estimate tempo, employee said "maybe 180, 182 beats per minute." Building has been closed since November. No charges filed.

VENTNOR - 11:47 PM: Woman reported seeing her deceased brother standing outside her home. Officers found no one at location. Woman became agitated when shown timestamp on police report, insisting she called "at least an hour earlier." Dispatch logs confirm call received at 11:47 PM. Woman declined medical attention.

MARGATE - 4:15 PM: Man reported finding "impossible photograph" in parking meter change return. Photo shows the man himself standing in same location, but "wearing different clothes I don't own." Photo dated three weeks in future. Man left photo with officers, departed before statement could be completed.

stories.headline: Local DJ Celebrates 20 Years at WFMU
stories.text:
EAST ORANGE - Tom Brennan has been spinning records at WFMU for two decades, but he's never forgotten his strangest broadcast.

It was 1977, during his late-night experimental music show. A caller requested "something at 182 beats per minute." Brennan, curious about the specific tempo, obliged with a punk track.

"The phone lines lit up," Brennan recalls. "Seventeen different callers, all requesting the same tempo. Not the same song - just that exact speed."

What happened next still puzzles him. Every caller described hearing additional sounds through their radios - vocals that weren't on the record, instruments Brennan wasn't playing. Several claimed to hear their own voices mixed into the broadcast.

"I checked the equipment three times," he says. "Nothing was wrong. But when I played the air check tape the next day, those extra sounds were there. My engineer couldn't explain it."

The tape disappeared from the station archive in 1979. Brennan says he's made peace with the mystery: "Sometimes the signal finds something in the static. Maybe it's always been there, and we just tuned into it correctly that one night."

stories.headline: Classified Ads - Personals
stories.text:
LOST: Black Casio watch, stops at 11:47 every night then resumes. Sentimental value. If found, please call 609-555-0182. Ask for Michael. Do not attempt to change the time.

SEEKING: Others who hear the 182hz tone. Especially between midnight and 3am. Not tinnitus. It has a pattern. It's trying to say something. Reply to Box 447.

TO THE SEVENTEEN: I was supposed to be with you. My car broke down on Route 72. I've been waiting at the coordinates every Tuesday since June. The tower is still broadcasting. I can hear it in my fillings. Please respond if you're reading this. - E.M.

WANTED: Audio engineer to analyze tape recording from 1977 WFMU broadcast. Standard hourly rate. Must be comfortable with unexplained phenomena. Discretion required. 201-555-7290.

FOUND: Set of identical gray windbreakers (17) left in train station locker #182, Newark Penn. Unclaimed since June. Each has coordinates sewn inside collar. NJ Transit Lost & Found.

stories.headline: Corrections
stories.text:
CORRECTION: In our October 18 report on the incident at the Big Orb nightclub, we incorrectly stated that guitarist Eric Mendez left the venue at approximately 11:30 PM. Security footage shows Mendez on stage until 11:47 PM. We regret the error.

CORRECTION: The same article stated four witnesses reported seeing Mendez exit through the rear door. This is incorrect. Four witnesses reported seeing Mendez in four different locations simultaneously during the final song. The Times apologizes for any confusion.

CORRECTION: We stated the band "Temporal Distortion" was performing their farewell show. The band has informed us this was not a farewell show, and they had additional performances scheduled. We apologize for the error. [Editor's note: All subsequent scheduled performances have been cancelled.]

CORRECTION: Our report stated mirrors from the Sarah Vance installation "reflected" audience members. Ms. Vance has contacted us to clarify that the mirrors were not traditional reflective surfaces but rather "temporal apertures." The Times does not fully understand this distinction but prints the correction as requested.

stories.headline: Obituaries - June 23, 1993
stories.text:
MENDEZ, Eric Thomas, 25, of Montclair, died June 23, 1992. Memorial service 2 PM Saturday, First Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Montclair Music Education Fund.

Survived by mother Patricia Mendez; father Robert Mendez; sister Jennifer Castellano.

Eric was a guitarist, sound engineer, and experimental musician. He performed with local bands Temporal Distortion and The Frequency Seekers. Friends remember his fascination with the physics of sound and his belief that "music could open doors."

[Editor's note: The family has requested we print the date as listed, though records show Eric Mendez was reported missing October 17, 1990. The family maintains that "Eric completed his transmission" on June 23, 1992, and considers that his actual date of death. We have honored their request.]

stories.headline: Classified Ads - Personals
stories.text:
TO THOSE WHO HEAR IT: The tone is not in your head. It's in the gaps between stations. Tune to 88.2 FM at exactly 11:47 PM. Listen to the static. Count the pulses. 182 per minute means you're close. Reply Box 182.

SEEKING MUSICIANS: for experimental project exploring "carrier frequencies." Must be willing to play at specific tempos. Rehearsals midnight to 3 AM only. Equipment provided. No prior experience necessary but you must hear the tone first. 609-555-1847

BOARDWALK ARCADE 1977: To the girl who played the broken pinball machine that showed tomorrow's scores. You said you'd meet me when it happened again. Still waiting. Still playing. Machine was removed in '78. I kept the coin. -M

FOUND: Seventeen identical notebooks left on Convention Hall steps after Ramones show. Each filled with same equation. Each signed with different name. Keeping them until claimed. Describe equation to prove ownership.

WHO WERE THE SEVENTEEN? Saw you at Stone Pony, all wearing gray. You left before encore. You left your watches. All stopped at same time. Call 201-555-0117 if you want them back.

stories.headline: Vandalism Report: CBGB's Bathroom Documentation Project
stories.text:
Documentary photographer Lynn Santos has been cataloging bathroom graffiti at punk venues across New Jersey. Her exhibit "Written on Walls" opens this month at Rutgers. Several recurring patterns deserve mention:

MAXWELL'S (Hoboken): Seventeen different hands have written "182" on the same stall door over past year. Management paints over it weekly. Reappears in different handwriting each time. Sometimes in different languages.

CITY GARDENS (Trenton): Equation covering entire wall in men's room: "f = 182hz → t = 11:47 → r = 17." Below it: "carrier frequency = manifestation threshold." Author unknown. Written in mirror script (readable only in reflection).

THE PIPELINE (Newark): Someone carved coordinates into metal stall divider with what appears to be acid etching: "40.8157, -74.2107." Below it: "They went through here."

FAST LANE (Asbury Park): Recurring phrase in seven different venues: "THE SIGNAL FINDS ITS OWN FREQUENCY." Always in capitals. Always same handwriting despite different locations miles apart. Santos confirmed handwriting matches across all seven sites.

WEST ORANGE VFW HALL: Wall behind stage covered in tally marks. Exactly 182 marks arranged in seventeen groups. Venue manager says marks reappear after painting. "I've covered that wall six times. It's always 182. Always seventeen groups. I stopped counting."

Santos notes: "What interests me isn't the vandalism - it's the coordination. These aren't random teenagers. Someone is leaving breadcrumbs."

stories.headline: Unexplained CB Radio Interference - FCC Investigates
stories.text:
FCC officials are investigating reports of coordinated interference on CB Channel 17 affecting truckers on Routes 72 and 206 near the Pine Barrens. 

Truckers report hearing what driver Mike Torres describes as "people counting backwards from 182 in different languages, all at the same time." The interference occurs exclusively between 11:45 PM and midnight.

From complaint transcripts:

[11:47 PM, 12/4/85]
UNKNOWN VOICE 1: "...eighty-two, eighty-one, eighty..."
TRUCKER: "Someone get off this channel, I got traffic here."
UNKNOWN VOICE 2: [different voice] "...one hundred seven, one hundred six..."
UNKNOWN VOICE 3: [child's voice] "Seventeen. Always seventeen. Count them."
TRUCKER: "What the hell is going on?"
[Carrier tone, 182hz, measured by FCC equipment]
UNKNOWN VOICE 4: "They're close now. Can you feel it in your fillings?"
[Signal terminates 11:47:59 PM]

Similar reports from seventeen different drivers over three consecutive nights. No source for transmission located. FCC triangulation suggests signal originates from decommissioned radio tower in Bass River State Forest, but tower has no power supply.

One driver, who declined to be named, provided coordinates where he experienced "time distortion" - his dashboard clock ran backwards for several miles. Coordinates match location of FCC's triangulated source.

Investigation ongoing.

stories.headline: Concert Promotion Mysteries - Zine Investigation
stories.text:
Someone's been putting up show flyers that don't make sense. Here's what we've documented:

CITY GARDENS flyer found in Princeton: "TEMPORAL DISTORTION with The Frequency Seekers / October 17, 1990 / Doors 11:47 PM / $17 / FINAL TRANSMISSION." Flyer dated September 1989 - show is over a year away. City Gardens claims they haven't booked any band by that name.

MAXWELL'S flyer (Hoboken): Seventeen identical flyers stapled in perfect circle on telephone pole. Each lists different band name but same date/time: "11:47 PM, June 23, 1992." All have same tagline: "Carrier Frequency Achieves Manifestation Threshold." No venue address listed.

PIPELINE flyer (Newark): "THE SEVENTEEN / Live Equipment Test / Broadcast Frequency: 182hz / No Audience Permitted / If You Can Read This, Stay Away." Found on bathroom mirror at pipeline. Written backwards so it reads correctly in reflection.

Multiple venues report finding flyers INSIDE locked buildings - appearing overnight on walls that face no windows or doors. All share design elements: gray background, times listed in 24-hour format, coordinates printed in fine print at bottom (40.8157, -74.2107).

Weirdest: Flyer for Temporal Distortion show at Big Orb (Montclair) advertising "Final Performance - October 17, 1990" was found in 1987 time capsule at Montclair High School. Capsule was sealed 1982.

If you've seen these flyers or know who's making them, write to: MRR, P.O. Box 3852, Princeton, NJ 08540

stories.headline: Police Investigate Coordinated Answering Machine Messages
stories.text:
ESSEX COUNTY - Police are investigating reports of identical messages appearing on answering machines across seventeen households with no apparent connection.

Messages were received August 9 between 11:47 PM and 11:48 PM. All households report their answering machines show no record of incoming calls, though messages were present on tape.

Transcripts (voice described as "gender neutral, possibly synthesized"):

"This is a courtesy notification. The transmission scheduled for June 23, 1992 will proceed as planned. You were selected based on frequency resonance. Coordinates are 40.8157, -74.2107. Carrier frequency is 182 hertz. Prepare seventeen. This message will not repeat."

Recipients include: a librarian in Montclair, an audio engineer in East Orange, three Rutgers students, a retired physicist, two high school music teachers, a sound equipment technician, and nine individuals with no obvious shared interests.

Common factors: All own or have access to audio recording equipment. All report experiencing "persistent tonal tinnitus at approximately 182 hertz" for the past 2-3 years. All are between ages 19 and 47. 

Dr. Patricia Mendez of Montclair received one such message. Her son, guitarist Eric Mendez, has been missing since October 1990.

"I haven't changed my number," she said. "How would anyone know to call me? And why this message about transmissions and frequencies? Eric talked about these exact things before he disappeared."

Phone company representatives confirm no calls were placed to these numbers on August 9. "The messages exist on the tapes," said spokesperson Linda Chen, "but according to our switching records, these phones never rang."

One recipient, Jake Castellano of Rutgers, recognized the coordinates. "Those are the same coordinates Eric had written inside his guitar pedal. I have no idea how anyone got my number, or why they're calling about June 1992. That's almost a year away."

Police have no suspects and have classified the incidents as harassment pending further investigation.

stories.headline: Letters to the Editor
stories.text:
THE 182 FREQUENCY

To the Editor: Has anyone else noticed the recurring appearance of "182" in local music venues? I've documented it at seventeen different shows in the past six months. Bands I've never heard of, all playing at exactly 182 BPM. When I ask who booked them, venue owners claim they have no record. One drummer told me: "We don't control the tempo. The tempo controls us." What does this mean? - M.S., Hoboken

MIRROR INSTALLATIONS

To the Editor: Your July 8 review of the Montclair State senior art show failed to mention the most disturbing piece: Sarah Vance's mirror installation. I attended the opening. The mirrors didn't reflect the room - they reflected the same room at different times. I saw myself entering the gallery in one mirror before I'd walked through the door. Other viewers experienced similar temporal displacement. The installation was removed after the first night. Why? - L.H., Montclair

MISSING MUSICIANS

To the Editor: Three guitarists from different bands have gone missing in North Jersey in the past year. All played experimental/noise rock. All built their own effects pedals. All disappeared around 11:47 PM. Police say these are unrelated cases. I disagree. Someone is targeting musicians who work with specific frequencies. If you play at 182 BPM or experiment with carrier tones, please be careful. - Anonymous

THE SEVENTEEN

To the Editor: Stop calling us a cult. We're listeners, not believers. The signal predates all of us. We simply responded to its frequency. Those who understand will find the coordinates. Those who don't should stop investigating. The transmission is not for everyone. - A Listener

stories.headline: Classified Ads - Lost and Found
stories.text:
LOST: Time between 11:47 PM and 12:34 AM, April 12. If found, please return to rightful owner. Missing 47 minutes. Last seen near coordinates 40.8157, -74.2107. Reward offered. No questions asked. 609-555-0182.

FOUND: Seventeen gray windbreakers, identical, abandoned at Cherry Hill Mall parking lot. Each has name tag inside: "M. Brennan" / "E. Mendez" / "S. Vance" / etc. All size medium. All brand new. If these are yours, call 609-555-7700. Please explain why you left them.

LOST: Memory of October 17, 1980. Know I was somewhere important. Have photos from that night showing me in place I don't recognize. If you were there, if you remember, please contact Box 182. My family says I came home at 3 AM with frost in my hair. It was 68 degrees that night.

FOUND: Tape recording labeled "Big Orb Rehearsal 10/17/1990." Tape is from 1981. Recording is dated nine years in future. Sounds like live band but venue says Big Orb doesn't open until 1985. Keeping tape safe. If it's yours, describe the band's name to claim it.

LOST: Ability to remember my son's face. Have photos but when I look at them, his features blur. Started after he disappeared. Doctor says this is impossible. Others who knew him say they experience same thing. If you remember Eric Mendez clearly, please call his mother. 973-555-1847.

SEEKING: The other sixteen. We all heard it at the same time. We all wrote down the same coordinates. We promised to meet there. I've been waiting since 1977. Where are you? - First of Seventeen

stories.headline: Public Notices
stories.text:
BASS RIVER STATE FOREST CLOSURE NOTICE

The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection announces temporary closure of fire roads accessing grid coordinates 40.8157, -74.2107 and surrounding 0.5-mile radius. Closure effective immediately.

Reason: Unexplained equipment malfunction affecting compasses, radio communication, and timekeeping devices. Forest Service personnel report persistent 182-hertz tone audible within closure zone. Source undetermined.

Duration: Until further notice. 

Violators subject to prosecution.

---

NOTICE TO HEIRS - Estate of Marion Vance (deceased 1955)

All persons claiming inheritance from the Vance estate are required to contact Probate Court by October 17, 1990. Failure to claim will result in property transfer to designated alternate beneficiaries.

[Editor's note: Original notice filed 1955. Required publication date error showing 1990 has been corrected multiple times but continues to print incorrectly. Legal counsel advises date should read "October 17, 1955" but typesetting equipment produces "1990" despite corrections. Running as filed.]

---

LOST PROPERTY AUCTION - State of NJ

Unclaimed items held by NJ State Police will be auctioned October 12, 1978, 10 AM, Trenton headquarters. Items include: Seventeen digital watches (all displaying same time: 11:47); gray windbreakers (qty 17); audio cassette tapes (17, unlabeled); one (1) homemade guitar effects pedal with note reading "If you can hear this, you're already part of it."

Minimum bid: $1 per lot. Cash only.

stories.headline: Vintage Vinyl - Store Inventory Anomalies
stories.text:
PRINCETON - Owner Tom Hendricks of Vintage Vinyl on Nassau Street is seeking help identifying several records that appeared in his store's inventory without being purchased or delivered.

From store incident log:

November 2, 1987: Found seventeen identical albums in "New Arrivals" bin. Label: "The Seventeen." Album title: "Carrier Frequency." No record company listed. Catalog number: VV-182-1990. Pressing plant code suggests manufactured three years in future. Grooves appear normal but playback produces only 182hz tone for 47 minutes. No other audio content.

Receipt printer logged these as sold on October 17, 1990 at 11:47 PM. Store has been open since 1982. Receipt shows customer name "E. Mendez" though no such transaction occurred.

November 3: Customer attempted to special order album by "Temporal Distortion." When asked for more details, customer showed me flyer for show at "Big Orb, Montclair, October 17, 1990." I informed customer it's currently 1987. Customer left confused. Flyer left on counter. Flyer is printed on paper stock not yet commercially available per my supplier.

Same day: Found cassette tape in used bin labeled "Big Orb Live Recording 10/17/90 - INFORMATION SEEKING FLESH." Tape housing dated 1990. When played, recording includes audience chatter mentioning "it's 1990" and "this is their last show." Recording quality suggests live venue but includes frequencies beyond cassette tape capability.

All items logged as "inventory origin unknown." Available for examination by appointment. Not for sale - attempting to locate rightful owners or determine if these are elaborate pranks.

Note: Seventeen customers have called asking about "the 182 recordings" in the past week. All describe same items. None can explain how they knew we had them.

Contact: Vintage Vinyl, 609-924-7800

stories.headline: Math Class Mystery: Same Coordinates Appear in 17 Students' Homework
stories.text:
By Jennifer Castellano, Junior Reporter

Something weird happened in Mr. Patterson's AP Calculus class last week. Seventeen students turned in homework with the same wrong answer - but it wasn't even an answer to the question he asked.

The assignment was about calculating derivatives. Instead, seventeen students wrote coordinates: "40.8157, -74.2107" at the bottom of their papers. All seventeen insist they don't remember writing it.

"I finished my homework around 11:30 PM," said senior Marcus Webb. "When I looked at it in the morning, those numbers were there in my handwriting. I don't remember writing them."

Mr. Patterson called it "mass hysteria" and gave everyone a chance to redo the assignment. But Sarah Vance, a senior planning to study art at Montclair State, looked up the coordinates. They point to somewhere in the Pine Barrens near an old radio tower.

"Why would seventeen of us write the exact same random coordinates?" Vance asked. "And why do I feel like I need to go there?"

More strange: all seventeen students were born in 1971, making them 17-18 years old. All report hearing "a faint ringing sound, like 182 cycles per second" (yes, they all somehow knew the exact frequency) late at night. All own Casio watches that occasionally stop at 11:47 PM.

When interviewed separately, several students mentioned "the transmission" without being asked about it. None could explain what transmission they meant.

Junior Eric Mendez, who plays guitar in local band Temporal Distortion, had an additional note on his homework: "This is where it happens. This is where information becomes flesh. October 17, 1990, 11:47 PM."

Mr. Patterson has referred the matter to school counselors. The seventeen students are fine, if confused. But here's the weirdest part: when Patterson checked his grade book from previous years, he found the same coordinates written in margins going back to 1983 - always in the homework of exactly seventeen students, always in April.

"I don't remember writing these notes," Patterson said. "I don't remember these students having this problem before. But the evidence is in my own handwriting."

The Mountaineer attempted to drive to the coordinates last weekend. Our car's odometer added 47 extra miles during a trip that should have been 32 miles. Our watches all stopped at 11:47 PM. We never found the tower.

We're not going back.

stories.headline: Classified Ads - Personals
stories.text:
JUNE 23 AT THE COORDINATES: I'll be there. Will you? Bring nothing but yourself and something to record the signal. The frequency knows who's ready. -One of Seventeen

TO E.M.: Your pedal is speaking again. Found it in my apartment though I never took it from your room. It wants to go home. Home is 40.8157, -74.2107. Will bring it there June 23, 11:47 PM. If you're still listening, you'll hear it calling. -J.C.

SEEKING: Recording equipment that can capture frequencies above 20khz. Need by June 20. Standard rental rates. Project involves documenting "carrier tone phenomenon" in Pine Barrens. Serious inquiries only. Must be comfortable with unexplained temporal effects. 908-555-0182

FOR THOSE WHO DISAPPEARED: We see you in the mirrors. We hear you in the static between stations. We know you're not gone - you're just broadcasting on a frequency we can't quite tune to yet. June 23 we try again. -The Listeners

LOST: Three years between 1989-1992. Have scattered memories of building something. Have photos of myself at locations I never visited. Have recordings of my voice saying things I don't remember. If you were with me during the missing time, call 732-555-1847. Ask for Marcus. Please help me remember.

WARNING: Do not go to Pine Barrens coordinates June 23. Seventeen people already committed. No more needed. Signal is at capacity. If you go anyway, you may not return in recognizable form. This is not metaphor. -A Former Listener

TO MY MOM: If I don't come back from the tower, know that I chose this. The signal has been calling since I was born. June 23 is when information finally becomes flesh. You'll understand when you can't remember my face anymore. That means it worked. -E.M.

THE SEVENTEEN ARE COMPLETE: No more seekers needed. Frequency locked. Manifestation threshold reached. Transmission scheduled June 23, 1992, 11:47 PM exactly. Those who must be there already know. Those reading this who feel nothing should be grateful. The signal is not for everyone.

stories.headline: Brief: State Forest Incident Under Investigation
stories.text:
BASS RIVER - State Police continue to investigate an incident Tuesday night at a decommissioned radio tower in Bass River State Forest. Details remain limited.

Rangers discovered the site Wednesday morning: electronic equipment, seventeen empty sleeping bags arranged in a circle, and what officials describe as "unusual ground markings."

No individuals were found at the scene. No vehicles were located in the area. Search dogs lost the scent at the tower's base.

State Police declined to comment on reports of "temporal anomalies" documented during the incident. Dashboard camera footage from the scene has been classified as evidence and is not available for public review.

The tower, abandoned since 1978, was found to be transmitting a signal at the time of discovery. FCC engineers disabled the broadcast Wednesday afternoon. The tower's power source could not be determined.

Anyone with information should contact State Police at (609) 882-2000.

The site remains closed to the public.
stories.location: Bass River State Forest, New Jersey
